entry of 'crack'
A hard, brittle, brownish gelatin, obtained by boiling the hides and hoofs of animals to a jelly; when gently heated with water, it is used as a cement for uniting substances.

Origin: apparently produced by a confusion of the synonymous scrat n., cratch v.

CommentOnOEDFullSense: A single seed of a plant, esp. one which is small, hard, and roundish in form. => extended to A small, hard, usually roundish particle (e.g. of sand, gold, salt, pepper). with a grain of salt => Any of the irregularly shaped discrete particles or crystals in a rock or a metal, usu. but not necessarily small:
callous

AlternativeForm: barb bhardh-a (if it goes back to beard?)

CommentOnOEDFullSense: burble > bubble > bubbly; The English word can hardly have any actual connection with these, except as a parallel onomatopoeia, expressing the sound made by the agitation, issuing forth, or flowing of a liquid mixed with vesicles of air or gas. Of this the later bubble n. appears to have been either a simple variant or a conscious modification.
Onomatopoeic: the v.n. of action being probably coeval.
started off meaning ordinary, common, mean!!
original meaning:  trans. To strengthen (morally or spiritually); to encourage, hearten, inspirit, incite. Obs.
onomatopoetic modification of flappy; the voiced ending in flab- as compared with flap- gives to the syllable a feebler effect suited to the meaning

Origin: possibly onomatopoetic formation suggested by film

CommentOnOEDFullSense: apparently connected with flue n.2; perhaps an onomatopoeic modification of that word, imitating the action of puffing away some light substance;

CommentOnOEDFullSense: rub = 'to apply pressure and friction', rubber = 'a sharp iron instrument in cutting off the superfluous nap of worsted'
entry of 'sequin'
To make smooth (and usually glossy) by friction; (in later use also) to apply polish to or rub polish into. Also with¾up. Also: to make bright (obs.¾rare). => weakening of friction sense?
Perhaps imitative of the action of blowing away light particles
